title: Antiamuny and Slider Movement
statementHtml:
Antiamuny is managing nn sliders on a one-dimensional track of length mm. Each slider occupies exactly one unit of space and starts at a distinct position. The sliders are numbered from 11 to nn and are arranged from left to right, so that the ii-th slider is initially at position aiai.

Antiamuny is given qq operations. Each operation is described by two integers ii and xx (1≤i≤n1≤i≤n, i≤x≤m−n+ii≤x≤m−n+i). The operation moves the ii-th slider to position xx. However, if this move causes a collision with another slider (i.e., if there is any other slider between the ii-th slider's current position and the destination xx), that obstructing slider is pushed in the same direction by one unit until it no longer causes a collision with the ii-th slider. This can trigger a chain reaction, where one slider pushes another, and so on, until all sliders occupy distinct positions again.

Importantly, note that the operations do not change the relative ordering of the sliders: the ii-th slider from the left will remain as the ii-th slider from the left. Furthermore, the constraints on xx ensure that all sliders always remain on the track, with positions between 11 and mm.

For example, suppose the initial slider positions are [1,3,5,7,9][1,3,5,7,9]. If the fifth slider (at position 99) is moved to position 66, it will push the fourth slider from 77 to 55, which in turn pushes the third slider from 55 to 44. The resulting positions become [1,3,4,5,6][1,3,4,5,6].

Unfortunately, Antiamuny has forgotten the order in which the qq operations were applied. To recover the results, he decides to independently simulate each of the q!q! possible permutations of the operations. For each permutation pp of length qq∗∗, define fi(p)fi(p) as the final position of the ii-th slider after applying the operations in the order specified by pp.

In other words, starting from the initial positions of a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an, Antiamuny first applies the p1p1-th operation, then the p2p2-th operation, and so on, until the pqpq-th operation. The value of fi(p)fi(p) is the position of the ii-th slider at the end of this sequence of operations.

Your task is to compute, for each slider ii (1≤i≤n1≤i≤n), the sum of fi(p)fi(p) over all q!q! permutations pp of the operations. Since the result can be large, output each sum modulo 109+7109+7.

∗∗A permutation of length qq is an array consisting of qq distinct integers from 11 to qq in arbitrary order. For example, [2,3,1,5,4][2,3,1,5,4] is a permutation, but [1,2,2][1,2,2] is not a permutation (22 appears twice in the array), and [1,3,4][1,3,4] is also not a permutation (q=3q=3 but there is 44 in the array).
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1031≤t≤103). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains three integers nn, mm, and qq (1≤n,q≤5⋅1031≤n,q≤5⋅103, n≤m≤109n≤m≤109) — the number of sliders, the length of the track, and the number of operations, respectively.

The second line of each test case contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤a1<a2<…<an≤m1≤a1<a2<…<an≤m) — the initial positions of each slider.

Each of the next qq lines contains two integers ii and xx (1≤i≤n1≤i≤n, i≤x≤m−n+ii≤x≤m−n+i) — the index of the slider to move, and the position to move the slider to, respectively.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn and the sum of qq over all test cases does not exceed 5⋅1035⋅103.
outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output nn integers, where the ii-th of which represents the sum of fi(p)fi(p) over all q!q! permutations pp of the operations, modulo 109+7109+7.
noteHtml:
In the first test case:

  • If the operations are done in order [2,1,3][2,1,3], we first apply the second operation which moves the 22-nd slider to position 66; then apply the first operation, which moves the 55-th slider to position 66; and finally apply the third operation, which moves the 11-st slider to position 44. The positions of the sliders after each operation are shown in the figure below. The final positions of the sliders will be [4,5,6,7,8][4,5,6,7,8].
  • If the operations are done in order [1,2,3][1,2,3], the final positions of the sliders will be [4,6,7,8,9][4,6,7,8,9].
  • If the operations are done in order [1,3,2][1,3,2], the final positions of the sliders will be [4,6,7,8,9][4,6,7,8,9].
  • If the operations are done in order [2,3,1][2,3,1], the final positions of the sliders will be [2,3,4,5,6][2,3,4,5,6].
  • If the operations are done in order [3,1,2][3,1,2], the final positions of the sliders will be [2,6,7,8,9][2,6,7,8,9].
  • If the operations are done in order [3,2,1][3,2,1], the final positions of the sliders will be [2,3,4,5,6][2,3,4,5,6].

For slider 11, the sum of positions of the 66 different scenarios is 4+4+4+2+2+2=184+4+4+2+2+2=18.

For slider 22, the sum of positions of the 66 different scenarios is 5+6+6+3+6+3=295+6+6+3+6+3=29.

For slider 33, the sum of positions of the 66 different scenarios is 6+7+7+4+7+4=356+7+7+4+7+4=35.

For slider 44, the sum of positions of the 66 different scenarios is 7+8+8+5+8+5=417+8+8+5+8+5=41.

For slider 55, the sum of positions of the 66 different scenarios is 8+9+9+6+9+6=478+9+9+6+9+6=47.
